metadata.case_name: Y. Narayana Chetty & Chilla Pitchayya v. Income-tax Officer, Nellore

facts.text: The firm M/s. Bellapu Audeyya and Chilla Pitchayya was formed on April 20, 1936, and dissolved on March 31, 1948. It consisted of two partners, Chilla Pitchayya and Bellapu Audeyya.
Chilla Pitchayya started another firm in the name and style of G. Pitchayya Co. with partner R. Subba Rao. This firm was formed on July 30, 1941, and dissolved on March 31, 1949.

Bellapu Audeyya and Chilla Pitchayya formed another firm, Prabhat Textiles, with five other partners on December 1, 1941. It was dissolved by civil court decree on December 22, 1949, effective January 1, 1949.
All three firms carried on business in yarn and cloth and were registered under s. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act.
For assessment years 1943-44 and 1944-45, Income-tax Officer, Nellore (respondent 1), treated each firm as separate entity and passed separate assessment orders.
On August 14, 1951, respondent 1 issued notice under s. 34 against Prabhat Textiles.

In proceedings, respondent 1 held Prabhat Textiles fictitious, real partners C. Pitchayya and B. Audeyya; cancelled registration under r. 6B; passed fresh assessments as unregistered firm for 1943-44 on August 14, 1952, and 1944-45 on February 25, 1953.
Similar action taken by respondent 1 against the other two firms on same dates.

Y. Narayana Chetty, partner of Prabhat Textiles, filed Writ Petition No. 613 of 1952 in Madras High Court against respondent 1 under Art. 226, seeking writ of prohibition against proceedings per notice of August 14, 1951, and assessment order of August 14, 1952 for 1943-44.
Chilla Pitchayya filed Writ Petition No. 201 of 1953 for Prabhat Textiles 1944-45; No. 629 of 1952 and No. 202 of 1953 for other firms' 1943-44 and 1944-45.
Four writ petitions heard together and dismissed by Madras High Court on March 5, 1954.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 r/w O. XLV rr. 1,2,3,8 that value exceeded Rs. 20,000.
Y. Narayana Chetty appellant in Civil Appeal No. 317/1957; Chilla Pitchayya in 318,319,320/1957.
High Court noted appellants admitted filing appeals against challenged orders.
Notice under s.34 served on appellant C. Pitchayya on behalf of firms; averred under-assessment; required return within 35 days; Pitchayya appeared.
Appellants made applications under s.27 against fresh assessment orders.
ITO finding: only B. Audeyya and C. Pitchayya had interest in the three firms; B. Audeyya did not challenge proceedings.
Appellant had notice and opportunity before cancellation under r.6B.

legal_issues.text: Whether proceedings under s.34 are invalid because notice issued to firms instead of individual partners, as assessee under s.2(2) is partner per s.23(5).
Whether for dissolved firms, notices under s.34 must be issued to individual partners, not firm.
Whether r.6B is ultra vires, inconsistent with s.23(4), as only s.23(4) allows cancellation of registration.
Whether revised assessments illogical/illegal: original as registered, escaped income as unregistered.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.34 invalid as notice not issued to assessees (individual partners); service on firm/C. Pitchayya defective; condition precedent to reassessment.
For dissolved firms, s.63(2) applies only to existing firms; notices to individuals required.
Cancellation of registration under r.6B ultra vires Central Board of Revenue; inconsistent with s.23(4); no notice required under r.6B unlike s.23(4); no appeal against r.6B order.
Revised assessment illogical: cannot treat firm registered for original income, unregistered for escaped income same years.

respondent_arguments.text: Writ discretionary; High Court refused; SC slow to interfere.
Alternative remedy via appeals under Act; appellants filed appeals and s.27 applications.
No jurisdiction for writ of prohibition against tax authorities.

court_reasoning.text: Notice under s.34(1)(a) validly issued to firms; firm is assessee under s.3 (charging section); 'person' includes firm u/s 3(42) General Clauses Act; assessment process under ss.22,23 treats firm as assessee; partners' shares determined after firm's total income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Firm does not cease to be assessee under s.23(5); s.23(4) treats firm as assessee.

court_reasoning.text: Even for dissolved firms, notice to member (C. Pitchayya) valid u/s 63(2); no notice of discontinuance u/s 25(2); other partners no grievance; only Pitchayya & Audeyya interested per ITO.

r.6B valid; framed u/s 59; for fictitious firms (no genuine firm existed); distinct from s.23(4) penalty for defaults where firm genuine; empowers review of erroneous registration u/s 26A; notice/opportunity given here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No inconsistency; statutory as published in Gazette.

court_reasoning.text: Issue of illogical assessment not jurisdictional; raises merits; can be agitated in appeals/s.27 proceedings; not for writ of prohibition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court rightly examined merits despite alternative remedy.

holdings.text: Firm is assessee; notice u/s 34 to firm valid even post-dissolution via member.
r.6B intra vires; allows cancellation for fictitious firms, distinct from s.23(4).
Illogical assessment argument not for Art.226 writ; pursue in statutory appeals.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Ramsukh Motilal
precedents_cited.relevance: Notice u/s 34 condition precedent; invalid notice voids proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. K. Das Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Notice u/s 34 condition precedent; invalid notice voids proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ravula Subba Rao v. Commissioner of I.T., Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Rules 2 and 6 under s.59 not ultra vires (distinguished from r.6B).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs reassessment notices to firms, registration/cancellation, assessment of registered firms.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding Madras High Court's dismissal of writ petitions. Held proceedings under s.34 and cancellation under r.6B valid; last contention not for writ jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: The notice prescribed by s. 34 cannot be regarded as a mere procedural requirement; it is only if the said notice is served on the assessee as required that the Income-tax Officer would be justified in taking proceedings against him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes notice as condition precedent for s.34 validity.

key_quotes.text: Section 3 of the Act which is the charging section provides inter alia that ... tax ... shall be charged ... in respect of the total income of the previous year of every firm; in other words, a firm is specifically treated as an assessee by s. 3.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Firm is assessee, notice to firm valid.

key_quotes.text: Rule 6B has been made to clarify this position and to confer on the Income-tax Officer in express and specific terms such authority to review his own decision in the matter of the registration of the firm when he discovers that his earlier decision proceeded on a wrong assumption about the existence of the firm.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds validity of r.6B for fictitious firms.
